problem_text:
Let π be a set of primes. A finite group is called a Cπ-group if it possesses exactly one class of conjugate Hall π-subgroups. A finite group is called a Dπ-group if any two of its maximal π-subgroups are conjugate.
(a) In a Cπ-group, is an overgroup of a Hall π-subgroup always a Cπ-group?
An affirmative answer in the case 2 ∉ π follows mod CFSG from (F. Gross, Bull. London Math. Soc., 19, no. 4 (1987), 311–319).
(b) In a Dπ-group, is an overgroup of a Hall π-subgroup always a Dπ-group?
E. P. Vdovin, D. O. Revin
answer:
a) Yes, it is (E. P. Vdovin, D. O. Revin, Siberian Math. J., 54, no. 1 (2013), 22–28).
b) Yes, it is (N. Ch. Manzaeva, https://arxiv.org/pdf/1504.03137.pdf) and (E. P. Vdovin, N. Ch. Manzaeva, D. O. Revin, Sb. Math., 211, no. 3 (2020), 309–335).
